[[Eastern Ontario]] and Southern [[Quebec]] could see slightly higher amounts as a coastal low develops, and gives heavier snow. Northeastern United States are seeing snow, mix precipitation and rainfall. The heavier snowfall is towards New England and Maine.
Atlantic Canada is seeing [[blizzard]] like conditions. 15–40 cm is possible is some areas. Winter storm warnings and snowfall warnings are in place.
==March==
===March 1–4=== [[Image:March 2009 snowstorm aftermath in northern Virginia.jpg|thumb|215px|Snow on the ground in Mount Vernon, Virginia, in the aftermath of the storm]] A major winter storm which brought up to 16" of snow to parts of West Tennessee and Arkansas and up to 7" of snow to parts of Georgia (including the Atlanta area), Alabama (including Birmingham) and Mississippi gathered strength and moved northeastward, in the process crossing the Washington, D.C. metropolitan area before impacting the greater New York and greater Philadelphia areas. The storm was a large, widespread storm, with snow totals exceeding {{convert|8|in|mm}} across most of the tri-state area. as well as 3–7 inches north of [[Rockland County]], as well as scattered amounts of 17–20 inches in New Jersey and Pennsylvania.
On March 1 to 2 a heavy [[dust storm]] hits N.E. [[PRC|China]] and parts of [[Mongolia]]. It then parses over the [[Bo Hai Sea]] and the [[Yellow Sea]], finally dispersing over [[North Korea]] and [[South Korea]] in the 4th <ref>{{cite web|url=http://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/IOTD/view.php?id=8477 |title=Dust Storm over East Asia : Image of the Day |publisher=Earthobservatory.nasa.gov |accessdate=2011-03-19}}</ref>
===March 7=== On the 7th, heavy rain induced floods killed 52 in Bolivia, 19 in Peru, and 16 in Ecuador, said news reports.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/NaturalHazards/view.php?id=19668 |title=Heavy Rain Floods South America : Natural Hazards |publisher=Earthobservatory.nasa.gov |accessdate=2011-03-19}}</ref>
===March 9=== A quick late winter storm caused about 5–15 cm of snow in Metro Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada with cold wind chills as low as -10 °C and with sustained winds at about 20 km/h.
===March 13=== Snow storm strands 2 busses, 53 cars and 83 people on the [[Ust-Kamenogorsk-Georgiyevka highway]] in [[Kazakhstan]] on March 13.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.rian.ru/world/20090313/120543248.html |title=Snow storm strands 83 people on highway in Kazakhstan | World | RIA Novosti |publisher=En.rian.ru |date=2009-03-13 |accessdate=2011-03-19}}</ref>
===March 22=== Heavy snow and ice hits the [[Sea of Okhotsk]], [[Sakhalin Island]] and [[Primorsky Krai]] in Russia far east on March 22.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eosnap.com/?p=4709 |title=Earth Snapshot • Ice Around Sakhalin Island, in the Sea of Okhotsk – March 22, 2009 |publisher=Eosnap.com |accessdate=2011-03-19}}</ref>
===March 26–28=== A major blizzard hit [[Denver]] and other counties around the area on Thursday, March 26. Parts of the Front Range saw {{convert|18|in|mm}} of snow and schools around Denver were closed early. [[Denver International Airport]] canceled more than 400 planes departing and arriving. On Friday, March 27, the storm impacted [[Kansas]], northwestern [[Oklahoma]], and the [[Texas Panhandle]], with 12 to {{convert|24|in|mm}} of snow and blizzard conditions. Some areas around Pratt County, Kansas and Kiowa County, Kansas received 28" of Snowfall. Snow Drifts reached {{convert|10|ft|m}} high in [[Dalhart]], [[Texas]]. On Friday night and into Saturday, March 28, the storm system impacted the [[Kansas City Metropolitan Area|Kansas City]] area and northern parts of [[Missouri]], before moving into the [[Quad Cities]] area, [[Northern Illinois]] and Southern [[Wisconsin]] on Saturday night. Numerous areas here saw between 4 and 8" of snow. [[Waukegan]], [[Illinois]], saw around half a foot from this late-season winter blast.
==April==
===April 12–13=== A late major winter storm coming from [[New England]] was expected to hit the [[Maritime Provinces]] on [[Easter]]. 15–30 cm of snow is expected in most areas, and Halifax and southern areas were to see heavy rain.
==June==
===June 2=== Another 15 people and 10,000 head of [[cattle]] had died by this date in Mongolia. Snow also fell on Russia's [[Sakhalin]] island.
===June 6=== Heavy rain and storm with twister in Czech Republic
==July==
===July 1=== Heavy rain falls in parts of the [[Ukraine]].
===July 11=== July 11 saw heavy storms flood the Chinese city of [[Shuzou]], in [[Jiangsu]] Province.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.travelblog.org/Asia/China/Jiangsu/Suzhou/blog-407527.html |title=summer storm season and a wu gong |publisher=Travelblog.org |date=2009-06-11 |accessdate=2011-03-19}}</ref>
===July 17=== On July 17, flooding caused by heavy rain and hailstorms hit [[Nanaimo(mongolia)|Nanaimo]] village, and its environs as bad weather sweeps over most of [[Mongolia]], killing 24 people as it did so.<ref>{{cite web|author=David Mitenko |url=http://mitenko.blogspot.com/2009/07/flooding-and-pick-pockets.html |title=The Mongolian харийн: Flooding and lightning storms |publisher=Mitenko.blogspot.com |date=2009-07-21 |accessdate=2011-03-19}}</ref>
===July 24=== On July 24, the [[Dakar Rally]] stage in [[Mauritania]] due to heavy sandstorms and high winds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://automiddleeast.com/villiers-storms-into-dakar-lead-1/ |title=Villiers Storms Into Dakar Lead |publisher=AutoMiddleEast.com |date=2009-07-24 |accessdate=2011-03-19}}</ref>
==August==
===August 5–6=== August 5 and 6 saw the [[Maritime affairs department]] in [[Hainan]] province issued an emergency [[tropical storm]] warning to 20,000 fishing vessels in the [[South China Sea]] as Typhoons [[Morakot]] and [[2009 Pacific typhoon season#Tropical Storm Goni (Jolina)|Goni]], approached China's [[Guangdong]] Province. Heavy storms hit the cities of [[Guangzhou]], [[Zhuhai]] and [[Haikou]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.898.travel/page_en.php?xuh=10392 |title=Tropical storm Goni hits south China-Hainan International Tourism |publisher=898.travel |accessdate=2011-03-19}}</ref> More than 953,000 residents and more than 35,000 boats were evacuated back to shore in the eastern and southeastern provinces of the [[People's Republic of China]] as Typhoons [[Morakot]] approached <ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/8191951.stm|publisher=BBC News|title=One million in China flee typhoon|date=2009-08-09|accessdate=2009-08-09}}</ref> A fishing boat capsized with nine fishermen missing.<ref>{{cite web|author=Mu Xuequan|title=20,000 evacuated in SE China as typhoon Morakot nears; nine fishermen missing|publisher=Xinhua|date=2009-08-08|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-08/08/content_11844823.htm|accessdate=2009-08-07}}</ref> 3 people died in the [[PRC|China]] and 462 died in [[Taiwan]].
===August 4–10===
[[Blizzards]] in southern [[Brazil]], reached 1,000,000 people, closing roads. Maximum accumulation of snow 50 cm (20 in) and a minimum temperature of −7 °C (19 °F).
===August 21–28=== A stream of moisture that emerged from the [[Gulf of California]] brought rain to Southern California. A [[flash flood]] warning was issued for Central and Eastern [[San Diego]] County as a result of the rain. Later on, the system moved north and started to move towards the east coast on Sunday, August 23. The remaining thunderstorms lingered around in Central and Eastern San Diego County until Friday, August 28 before finally moving towards the east coast.
==September==
===September 2–8=== A heavy and rainy [[cyclone]] hit the [[Bering sea]], [[Choris Peninsula]] and parts of the [[Aleutian islands]] on September 2. A heavy storm hit parts of the [[Beaufort Sea]] and parts of the [[Chukchi Sea]] on September 4.
Heavy rain and floods on the 4th also lead to both cars were under water and bales of [[wheat]] are floating down the swollen river past Mr A.J. Duncan's farms at [[Muirden Farm]], [[Turriff]], [[Aberdeenshire]]. Both Oxbridge and Publican spring barley planting was at risk if the flood waters did not clear quickly.<ref>{{cite web|author=Olivia Cooper |url=http://www.fwi.co.uk/Articles/2009/09/04/117556/Harvest-09-Flooding-in-Aberdeen.htm |title=Harvest 09: Flooding in Aberdeen - 9/4/2009 - Farmers Weekly |publisher=Fwi.co.uk |date=2009-09-04 |accessdate=2011-03-19}}</ref>
On the 8th unusually heavy rain hit [[Argentina]],<ref name="ReferenceB">{{cite web|author=Updated 1 minutes ago 3/19/2011 9:50:58 PM +00:00 |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/32739217/ns/weather/ |title=Storm kills 15 in Argentina, Brazil - Weather - msnbc.com |publisher=MSNBC |accessdate=2011-03-19}}</ref> and storms hit Argentina, Brazil and Uruguay, killing 14 or 15 people (reports varied).<ref name="guardian.co.uk">{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/sep/08/argentina-tornado | location=London | work=The Guardian | title=Storm kills 14 in Argentina, Brazil and Uruguay | date=2009-09-08}}</ref> Tornados his Argentina to.<ref name="guardian.co.uk"/> A town official in [[Santa Rosa de Calchines|Santa Rosa]], [[Paulo Alvez]] appealed for help for both the town of Santa Rosa and [[El Progreso]].<ref name="ReferenceB"/>
Arkansas witnessed heavy flooding on the 7th and 8th.<ref name="ReferenceB"/>
==October==
===October 1–5=== A heavy and snowy cyclone hit the [[Kedrovaya River]] in [[Primorsky Krai]] and parts of the [[Aleutian islands]] on October 1.
A heavy and rainy cyclone hit the [[Bering sea]] and parts of the [[Chukchi Sea]] on October 3. 21 people were confirmed dead following rainstorms and landslides in [[Sicily]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.euronews.net/2009/10/03/21-confirmed-dead-in-sicily-rainstorms-and-landslides/ |title=21 confirmed dead in Sicily Rainstorms and Landslides - Natural disasters : news, world |publisher=euronews |accessdate=2010-02-26}}</ref> A [[fishing boat]] was damaged at sea off the coast of Sicily. Austria saw heavy flooding, with lesser levels in the [[Czech Republic]], Poland, [[Slovenia]], [[Slovakia]], [[Romania]], [[Moldova]] and southern parts of [[Ukraine]]. Two Ukrainians and a Moldovan died in the storm.
5 days of unusually heavy rain left 205 dead, 125 injured and 750,000 homeless in southern India by October the 5th. Indian and [[Sri Lanka]]n medical teams managed to save many lives across [[Tamil Nadu]] and [[Kerala]] states.<ref>{{cite web|author=5 October 2009 |url=http://www.nce.co.uk/news/water/southern-india-besieged-by-floods/5208992.article |title=Southern India besieged by floods | Online news | New Civil Engineer |publisher=Nce.co.uk |date=2009-10-05 |accessdate=2011-03-19}}</ref>
===October 7–20=== {{Main|October 2009 North American storm complex}}
Late on October 11, the disorganized remnants of [[Typhoon Melor (2009)|Super Typhoon Melor]] were absorbed by another low-pressure system just north of it,<ref name="wunderground.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.wunderground.com/blog/JeffMasters/comment.html?entrynum=1350 |title=Wunder Blog : Weather Underground |publisher=Wunderground.com |accessdate=2010-02-26}}</ref> similar to how [[Typhoon Kujira (2009)|Typhoon Kujira]]'s remnants were absorbed by another extratropical system. The extratropical cyclone rapidly intensified as it neared the [[Pacific Northwest]]. Several wind and flood watches/warnings were issued on October 17 in advance for the expected arrival of the winter storm. A high wave advisory was issued for the entire western seaboard. Just before midnight of October 18, the powerful winter storm struck [[California]] with gale-force winds and torrential rainfall. In [[Northern California]], the rainfall was seemingly endless. The [[San Francisco Bay]]<ref name="wunderground.com"/> area suffered the most damage, from 40-foot (12 m) high waves and reported gusts of 85 mph (140 km/h). A rare storm warning was posted for San Francisco Bay and subsequently, wind gusts were clocked at 75 mph (125 km/h) on [[Angel Island (California)|Angel Island]]. While the main system remained offshore, the storm's moisture split into two new systems over the [[Western United States]], which rapidly moved eastward across the US, bringing strong winds and heavy rain. On December 20, after looping back north into the [[Gulf of Alaska]], the storm complex was absorbed by another stronger extratropical cyclone approaching from the west. The damage that the storm complex caused is currently estimated at about $1.18 million (2009 USD).
Heavy snow fell in parts of Pennsylvania between October 15 and 16. State College, Pennsylvania saw ten inches (254 mm) of wet snow, causing a very memorable Penn State homecoming game, and breaking numerous records, such as earliest recorded snowfall, most severe October snowstorm, and most snow in the month of October. Moderate snow fell between October 15 and 18 in the [[Northeastern United States]], as far as the suburbs of [[New York City]], with light snow being reported in the city itself. [[Boston]] suburbs saw moderate, wet snow fall on the morning of October 16, in spots accumulating up to {{convert|0.5|in|mm}}. The area was then hit on October 18, when in the afternoon, heavy rain turned to heavy snow and almost white-out conditions. The ground was too warm for any significant accumulation, but up to {{convert|2|in|mm}} were reported at spots between Boston and [[Lowell, Massachusetts|Lowell]]. All of the snow melted by October 20.
===October 12–13=== On 12 October 2009, Just over 200 herdsmen and 1,000 heads of [[livestock]] had been stranded by heavy snowfalls in [[Ali prefecture]]. The week-long snowfall had accumulated to about 30 centimetres in [[Pulan County]] in Ali, with some areas reaching as much as 1 meter depth, according to Xing Xiuyin, head of an [[armed police]] detachment stationed in the [[Tibet]]an region. 30 soldiers and two snow-clearing machines were sent on the way to Ali, according to Xing Xiuyin.<ref name="study-in-china.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.study-in-china.org/ChinaEducation/NewsOpinion/200910121116245000.htm |title=Tibet Snow Storm Strands More than 200 Herdsmen - Study In China |publisher=Study-in-china.org |accessdate=2010-02-26}}</ref> Thousands of people were trapped as heavy snow fell in Tibet's [[Lhunze County]], but rescue services managed to minimize the casualties and damage to homes. The rescue services also managed to provide shelter and emergency [[fodder]] for 200 head of cattle. By October 13, snow was reported by Chinese authorities to be falling in both [[Qinghai]] and [[Heilongjiang]] Provinces.
===October 15–16=== On 15 October 2009, Germany, Austria and Poland were hit by heavy snowstorms.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.rian.ru/photolents/20091015/156480257.html |title=Germany, Austria and Poland hit by snowstorms | Top Russian news and analysis online | 'RIA Novosti' newswire |publisher=En.rian.ru |date=2010-02-19 |accessdate=2010-02-26}}</ref> One person died after falling in a [[State of Tyrol|Tyrol]]ian lake by accident.
27,000 [[lightning]] strikes and heavy rainstorms hit parts of Spain in just over 12 hours on 16 October.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.euronews.net/2009/09/16/southern-spain-on-flood-alert/ |title=Southern Spain on flood alert - Flood : news, world |publisher=euronews |accessdate=2010-02-26}}</ref>
On October 16 the cold weather in Poland kills 4 people and the Czech power company [[CEZ Group]] declared a state of emergency in 8 regions due to the widespread reports of fallen power lines. The town of [[Jablonec nad Nisou]] was mostly [[power outage|blacked out]] by a [[power outage]]. Heavy snow was reported in Poland, the [[Czech Republic]], [[Slovakia]], [[Liechtenstein]] and the Austrian province of [[Styria]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tvnz.co.nz/world-news/european-cold-snap-kills-four-in-poland-3078456 |title=Cold snap kills 4 in Poland, cuts power to hundreds of thousands | WORLD News |publisher=Tvnz.co.nz |date=2009-10-16 |accessdate=2011-03-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091019071349/http://tvnz.co.nz/world-news/european-cold-snap-kills-four-in-poland-3078456 |archivedate=2009-10-19 |df= }}</ref>
===October 29–30=== Between October 29 and 30 a very powerful winter storm battered the west coast of the USA, although it did not affect [[Southern California]]. It was very windy in the places that it hit, but the storm only stayed there for two days. The storm left and traveled towards the east coast after that day. The only affect the storm had on Southern California was bringing a cloudy day with very cold temperatures.
===October 31=== Heavy snowfall hit Russia's [[Primorsky Krai|Primorsky]] Territory on October 31, as the cold windstorm moved from the [[Sea of Okhotsk]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/International/2009/10/31/Russia-enduring-cyclonic-snow-storm/UPI-56511257013824/ |title=Russia enduring cyclonic snow storm |publisher=UPI.com |date=2009-10-31 |accessdate=2010-02-26}}</ref><ref name="officialwire.com">{{cite web|author1=Heather Stewart |author2=Greg Palast |url=http://www.officialwire.com/main.php?action=posted_news&rid=36311 |title=Russia Enduring Cyclonic Snow Storm |publisher=OfficialWire |accessdate=2010-02-26}}</ref> to the coast of the [[Kamchatka Peninsula]], bringing heavy snow and rain to the region that meteorologists expected to last another 24 hours. They also warned that temperatures would fall by up to 15 degrees <ref name="officialwire.com"/> and that weather conditions could make traveling difficult as snowfall in the [[Vladivostok]] area had already significantly impeded travel by larger vehicles. The city administration's official [[Yevgeny Kolpinets]] told the Russian news agency Itar-Tass that the inclement weather had stopped bus traffic in the city, but luckily no energy supply service problems had been reported.<ref name="officialwire.com"/> [[Weather forecast]]ers expected more cyclone-generated snow fall over the next few days.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/Interational/2009/10/31/Russia-enduring-cyclonic-snow-storm/UPI-56511257013824/ |title=Russia enduring cyclonic snow storm |publisher=UPI.com |date=2009-10-31 |accessdate=2010-02-26}}</ref>
==November==
===November 3–18===
On November 3, the [[Harbin Snow Festival]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.torontosun.com/news/world/2010/01/05/12351751.html |title=Harbin Ice and Snow Festival | World | News |publisher=Toronto Sun |date=2010-01-05 |accessdate=2010-02-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kansascity.com/934/gallery/1669877.html |accessdate=January 13, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100111073701/http://www.kansascity.com/934/gallery/1669877.html |archivedate=January 11, 2010 }}</ref> <ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/gallery/2010/01/07/GA2010010702523.html |title=Harbin ice and snow festival |publisher=washingtonpost.com |date=2010-01-05 |accessdate=2010-02-26}}</ref> in [[Harbin]], [[Heilongjiang]], China, experienced unusually heavy snow. The festival was first started in 1985<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.travelchinaguide.com/attraction/heilongjiang/harbin/ice_snow.htm |title=Harbin Ice Festival, bing xue jie, Heilongjiang |publisher=Travelchinaguide.com |accessdate=2010-02-26}}</ref> and had never before seen such heavy snowfall. Harbin is China's tenth-largest city with a population of about 4,500,000,<ref>{{cite web|last=Dickson |first=Michael |url=http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1262339436219&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull |title=The reason that China matters | Op-Ed Contributors | Jerusalem Post |publisher=Fr.jpost.com |accessdate=2011-03-19 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> so planned electricity rationing would hit this usually busy city hard, as would the planned rationing in [[Beijing]]. The worst snowstorms in Northeastern China since 1949 claimed 40 lives, destroyed thousands of buildings and destroyed almost {{convert|500000|acres|0|abbr=on}} of winter crops, according to the [[Ministry of Civil Affairs of the People's Republic of China|Civil Affairs Ministry]]. The snowfall was the heaviest in the provinces of [[Hebei]], [[Shanxi]], [[Shaanxi]], [[Shandong]] and [[Henan]] since the founding of the [[People's Republic of China]] in 1949.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://article.wn.com/view/2009/11/14/Heavy_snow_storms_in_northern_China_kill_40/ |title=Heavy snow storms in northern China kill 40 - Worldnews.com |publisher=Article.wn.com |accessdate=2010-02-26}}</ref>
On November 4, [[Hurricane Ida (2009)|Tropical Storm Ida]] hits [[Nicaragua]] and later the [[Gulf of Mexico]]. The [[Lower Mississippi River Forecast Center]] puts out a flood alert on the [[Mississippi River]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nola.com/hurricane/index.ssf/2009/11/tropical_storm_ida_threatens_c.html |title=Tropical Storm Ida threatens Central America, could be in Gulf of Mexico by Monday |publisher=NOLA.com |date=2009-11-04 |accessdate=2011-03-19}}</ref> By November the 7th, a storm waning was also out in [[Pinar del Río]], in western [[Cuba]], as it headed out of [[Central America]] and in to southern [[Mexico]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://edition.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/weather/11/07/tropical.storm.ida/index.html | work=CNN | title=Tropical storm Ida could become hurricane -- again | date=November 8, 2009}}</ref> Winds of 70 mph (110 km/h) were forecast for [[Yucatán Peninsula]] and [[Yucatán Channel]]. Heavy rain was reported in parts of [[Haiti]]. A rainfall of 3 to {{convert|10|in|mm}} is predicted by local authorities and the Lower Mississippi River Forecast Center for both the Yucatán Peninsula and western Cuba. By the 10th, it had virtually died out and was only a bad storm in [[New Orleans]] and [[Pensacola]]. 35-45 M.P.H. winds and heavy rain battered the rest of [[Florida]]‘s [[Gulf Coast]] and [[Alabama]]'s [[Dauphin Island]].<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/11/11/us/11storm.html | work=The New York Times | title=Tropical Storm Ida Weakens as It Moves Ashore | first=Damien | last=Cave | date=2009-11-11}}</ref> The remnants of the storm then caused some more snow to fall in the southern parts the [[Great Plains]] on region the 11th and 12th.
On November 10, heavy rain and intermittent snow hit the [[Cheviot Hills]], [[Pennines]], [[Dee Valley]] in [[Wales]] and [[The Wash]]. Light snow fell in the [[Grampian Mountains]] and [[Aberdeenshire]].<ref name="monstersandcritics.com">[http://www.monstersandcritics.com/.../uk/.../Heavy rain storm sleet and snow hit Britain amid flooding]</ref> Passing [[Rain and snow mixed|sleet]] was also recorded in [[Lincolnshire]] on the 10th. A [[flood watch]] was put on the [[River Tay]] and the [[River Dee, Wales|River Dee]].<ref name="monstersandcritics.com"/> Minor surface flooding had already occurred in parts of Lincolnshire and [[Cumbria]] after the previous two days flooding.<ref name="monstersandcritics.com"/>
11 November 2009, saw snow and/or rain storms menacing Hungary, [[Iceland]], India's part of the [[Himalayas]] (rain and snow), parts of [[Indonesia]] (rain only), north western [[Iran]], northern Iraq, [[Mount Fuji]] in Japan and in [[Armenia]]. Yet more snow storms hit the [[People's Republic of China]], disrupting traffic across the northeastern provinces, [[Beijing]] and [[Tibet]] on November the 10th and 11th.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://life.globaltimes.cn/life/2009-11/484306.html |title=Global Times - Snow storms hit China, disrupt traffic |publisher=Life.globaltimes.cn |accessdate=2010-02-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100328025246/http://life.globaltimes.cn/life/2009-11/484306.html |archivedate=2010-03-28 |df= }}</ref> Most of [[Bulgaria]]'s poor [[drainage]] systems and second-rate [[storm drain]]s failed during the day's heavy rain and windstorms.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://elsapeters.com/mydiary/Blah.pl?m-1257220597/ |title=NOVEMBER,2009 - Elsa Peters Diary living in Bulgaria Elsa Peters diary of life as an expat |publisher=Elsapeters.com |accessdate=2010-02-26}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> Snow was also present in most of the mountain regions.
Heavy snowfall in China caused school [[structural failure|building collapse]]s and the deaths of 38 people on the 18th.<ref>[http://www.nguoi-viet.com/absolutenm/anmviewer.asp?a=104095&z=5 Bão tuyết chưa từng thấy trong 60 năm ở Trung Quốc]{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} {{vi}}</ref>
=== November 10–13 === Floods on the 10th and 11th killed 8 in Brazil's [[Rio Grande do Sul]], according to the state's Civil Defence Department. 4 others were killed in Argentina and Uruguay. 22,000 people were evacuated in each nation as heavy rain made the rivers between Uruguay and Argentina to overflow its banks.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/world/2009-11-25-South-America_N.htm | work=USA Today | title=South America floods kill 12; thousands evacuate | date=2009-11-25}}</ref>
===November 11  – December 30=== After a rather snowy November 11, [[Iceland]]'s weather became rather unusual. From November 12 to December 30, Iceland's abnormally warm and dry November weather gave way and December became very snowy with the town of [[Akureyri]] receiving 35 cm of snow over the night of December 1–2.<ref name="lax-a.is">{{cite web|url=http://www.lax-a.is/news/news//nr/9424 |title=The winter has arrived in Iceland – Good news for next season fishing |publisher=Lax-a.is |date=2009-12-02 |accessdate=2010-02-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100204000102/http://www.lax-a.is/news/news |archivedate=2010-02-04 |df= }}</ref> Snow fell and [[blizzard]]s occurred intermittently throughout a windy December.<ref name="visionlogic.aminus3.com">{{cite web|url=http://visionlogic.aminus3.com/image/2009-12-30.html |title=Descending Snow Storm Over Glacier Plains, Iceland - Landscape & Rural Photos - dj.tigersprout's photoblog |publisher=Visionlogic.aminus3.com |accessdate=2010-02-26}}</ref>
On December 12, heavy snow hit [[Dimmuborgir]], [[Iceland]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lythorse.com/en/news/part4.html |title=Lýtingsstaðir |publisher=Lythorse.com |accessdate=2010-02-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714010626/http://www.lythorse.com/en/news/part4.html |archivedate=2011-07-14 |df= }}</ref>
===November 14=== A blizzard and about half a foot of snow fell on the 1,040 m high [[Peak Chekhov]], near [[Yuzhno]], [[Sakhalin Island]], on November 14, 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://p6.hostingprod.com/@treks.org/pb_sakhalin08.htm |title=Chekhov Peak, 1040 m, Yuzhno, Sakhalin Island, 14 November 2009 |publisher=P6.hostingprod.com |date=2009-11-14 |accessdate=2010-02-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090716094145/http://p6.hostingprod.com//%40treks.org//pb_sakhalin08.htm |archivedate=16 July 2009 |df= }}</ref>
===November 18–25=== {{Main|2009 Great Britain and Ireland floods}} [[File:Workington 2009 flood.jpg|thumb|175px|The approach to [[Calva Bridge]], [[Workington]], 20 November 2009.]] [[File:Banbury snowy street Nov 20, 2009.jpg|thumb|175px|A snowy Banbury street on Nov' 20, 2009.]]
Many properties were flooded in [[Ambleside]] on November 18, leaving the main road impassible for most vehicles.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8369699.stm|title=Cumbria floods: Your stories|date=20 November 2009|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=20 November 2009}}</ref> Over 200 people in [[Cockermouth]] were rescued from their homes by the emergency services.<ref name="BBC8366360">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8366360.stm|title=More than 200 people rescued in floods in Cumbria town|publisher=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=20 November 2009 | date=2009-11-20}}</ref>
On the [[Isle of Man]], there were brief power cuts on the 18th, in [[Ballaragh]] and [[Laxey]] but [[Manx Electricity]] restored power to all affected properties by the afternoon.<ref name=BBC8369886>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/isle_of_man/8369886.stm |title=Isle of Man ferry service resumes |publisher=BBC News Online |accessdate=21 November 2009 | date=2009-11-20}}</ref>
On the 20th, all services on the [[West Coast Main Line]] were still temporarily suspended after a landslip between [[Carlisle railway station|Carlisle]] and [[Penrith railway station|Penrith]]. The West Coast Main Line was flooded between [[Carlisle railway station|Carlisle]] and [[Carstairs railway station|Carstairs]] and was closed as a result. Services were reduced between [[Edinburgh Waverley railway station|Edinburgh]] and [[Glasgow Queen Street railway station|Glasgow]] and also Edinburgh and Dunblane.<ref name=BBC8369799>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/south_of_scotland/8369799.stm |title=Rail services affected by heavy rain |publisher=BBC News Online |accessdate=20 November 2009 | date=2009-11-20}}</ref> [[File:Calva Bridge, Workington.jpg|thumb|175px|Calva Bridge, [[Workington]] in [[Cumbria]], which was condemned as a result of damage received in the flooding.]]
In [[Workington]], the collapse of [[Northside Bridge]] carrying the [[A597 road (Great Britain)|A597 road]] and the condemnation of [[Calva Bridge]] carrying the [[A596]] resulted in a {{convert|40|mi|km}} journey from Northside to the town centre.<ref name=BBC8373577>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8373577.stm |title=Cumbria flood areas face school and road closures |publisher=BBC News Online |accessdate=23 November 2009 | date=2009-11-23}}</ref> [[Network Rail]] are constructed a temporary railway station, [[Workington North railway station|Workington North]], to help Northside residents get into and out of town.<ref>[http://www.planningresource.co.uk/news/ByDiscipline/Transport/969060/Temporary-rail-station-help-Workington-flood-victims/ Temporary rail station....] Planning Resource</ref> The 170 members of the [[Royal Engineers]] from 170 (Infrastructure Support Unit) installed a temporary footbridge upstream of Calva Bridge, which opened as scheduled, on 5 December 2009.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/cumbria/8381395.stm | title=BBC News - Motorists cross flood-hit bridge | accessdate=2009-11-26 | date=2009-11-26}}</ref>
As a result of the loss of all road and footbridges in [[Workington]] on November 19, it was announced that a new [[ailway station]], [[Workington North railway station|Workington North]], would be built on wasteland leased for two years from [[Allerdale|Allerdale Council]].<ref name=BBC8375623>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/cumbria/8375623.stm |title=Cumbria poised for more flooding |publisher=BBC News Online |accessdate=24 November 2009 | date=2009-11-24}}</ref> The station was scheduled to open by 28 November with services provided by [[Northern Rail (Serco-Abellio)|Northern Rail]].<ref name=NR>{{cite web|url=http://www.networkrailmediacentre.co.uk/content/detail.aspx?ReleaseID=4831&NewsAreaID=2&SearchCategoryID=5 |title=NETWORK RAIL TO BUILD NEW TEMPORARY STATION TO HELP WORKINGTON FLOOD VICTIMS |publisher=Network Rail |accessdate=24 November 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110929042128/http://www.networkrailmediacentre.co.uk/content/detail.aspx?ReleaseID=4831&NewsAreaID=2&SearchCategoryID=5 |archivedate=29 September 2011 |df= }}</ref> Workington North opened on 30 November 2009.<ref name="BBC8385635">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/cumbria/8385635.stm|title=Workington gets new rail station after Cumbria flood|work=BBC News Online|date=30 November 2009|accessdate=7 December 2009|first=Colette|last=Hume}}</ref>
The government pledged [[£]]1,000,000 to the reconstruction of the shattered town, but deemed any new (permanent) road or a (temporary) rail bridge unnecessary and only allowed the army engineers to build a temporary foot bridge at state expense to begin with. [[Northern Rail (Serco-Abellio)|Northern Rail]], [[Network Rail]] and a local contractor all helped in the building of [[Workington North railway station|Workington North]]. The [[Department for Transport]] announced that it would fund the service until 31 December 2009, at a cost of £216,000. All trains between [[Workington]], [[Workington North]], [[Flimby]] and [[Maryport]] would be free of charge until 31 December 2009.<ref>{{cite web|title=New hourly train to help reunite Cumbrian community |url=http://nds.coi.gov.uk/content/detail.aspx?NewsAreaId=2&ReleaseID=409070&SubjectId=2 |date=30 November 2009 |publisher=Department for Transport |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120224072117/http://nds.coi.gov.uk/content/detail.aspx?NewsAreaId=2&ReleaseID=409070&SubjectId=2 |archivedate=24 February 2012 |df= }}</ref>
Heavy sandstorms hit [[Mauritania]] on Nov 22.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.travbuddy.com/travel-blogs/63719/Riding-into-Saharan-sand-storm-20 |title=Riding into the Saharan sand storm along railway route - Middle of Nothingness, Mauritania - Travel Blog |publisher=Travbuddy.com |date=2009-11-22 |accessdate=2011-03-19}}</ref>
[[County Fermanagh]] was hit by heavy rain on November the 23rd. Many roads were flooded or hit by [[landslides]].<ref name="belfasttelegraph.co.uk">{{cite web|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/fermanagh-deluged-as-rain-storms-wreak-havoc-throughout-the-uk-14571843.html |title=Fermanagh deluged as rain storms wreak havoc throughout the UK - Local & National, News |publisher=Belfasttelegraph.co.uk |date=2009-11-23 |accessdate=2010-02-26}}</ref> The B36 Dernawilt Road between [[Enniskillen]] and [[Killyfole]] was one of many that were affected by the storm.<ref name="belfasttelegraph.co.uk"/> Both [[Lough Erne]] and the [[Colebrooke River]] were put on [[flood alert]].<ref name="belfasttelegraph.co.uk"/>
A mini-[[tornado]] tore through Maypole Lane in the [[Derbyshire]] village of [[Littleover]] the next day, November 24. [[Derbyshire Fire and Rescue Service]] reported moderate damage in the Village <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/lsquomini-tornadorsquo-rips-through-english-town-14572549.html |title='Mini tornado' rips through English town - Local & National, News |publisher=Belfasttelegraph.co.uk |date=2009-11-24 |accessdate=2010-02-26}}</ref> on the 24th. A small [[waterspout]] was reported off the coast of [[Aberdeenshire]].
25 November saw fierce winds rattling [[Dublin Airport]] and parts of the east coast of Ireland, leading to the diversion of ten aircraft—seven aircraft to [[Shannon Airport]] and three aircraft to [[Manchester Airport]].<ref name="Dublin airport hit by strong winds">{{cite news|author=Éanna Ó Caollaí|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2009/1125/breaking42.htm|title=Dublin airport hit by strong winds|date=2009-11-25|accessdate=2009-11-27|work=[[The Irish Times]]}}</ref> Some of the affected aircraft were transatlantic flights from destinations such as [[Chicago]] and New York.<ref name="Flights diverted because of stormy weather">{{cite news|author=Fergus Black|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/flights-diverted-because-of--stormy-weather-1953689.html|title=Flights diverted because of stormy weather|date=2009-11-26|accessdate=2009-11-27|work=[[Irish Independent]]}}</ref>
===November 21 – December 3=== {{Main|Typhoon Nida (2009)}}
[[File:Nida 2009 track.png|thumb|left|175px|Typhoon Nida's storm path]] Early on November 21 the [[Joint Typhoon Warning Center]] (JTWC) reported that an area of convection had persisted within a monsoon trough about 880 km, (545 mi) to the southeast of [[Guam]].<ref name="STWA 2009-11-21 06z">{{cite web|url=ftp://ftp.met.fsu.edu/pub/weather/tropical/GuamStuff/2009112106-ABPW.PGTW |title=Significant tropical weather advisory for the Western and South Pacific Ocean 2009-11-21 06z |date=2009-11-21 |publisher=[[Joint Typhoon Warning Center]] |accessdate=2009-11-22 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref name="TCFA 2009-11-21 11z">{{cite web|url=ftp://ftp.met.fsu.edu/pub/weather/tropical/GuamStuff/2009112111-WTPN.PGTW |title=Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert 2009-11-21 1100z |date=2009-11-21 |publisher=[[Joint Typhoon Warning Center]] |accessdate=2009-11-22 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The typhoon later weakened to a category four, before re-strengthening to a category five on November 27, remaining quasi-stationary for more than two days. It weakened to a tropical depression on December 2, after sending bursts of moisture into the [[jet stream]]. The storm dissipated on December 3.
===November 25–30=== On November 25, a cold extratropical cyclone tracked into Russia's [[Primorsky Krai|Primorsky]] Territory from the [[Yellow Sea]]. [[Weather forecasters]] correctly predicted snow, [[gale]]-force wind and temperatures between 0 and −2 °C, with one night's temperature drop reaching −25°С. Over the next week the daytime temperature was predicted to be between 2°С to -10°С, with a nighttime temperature between −24 and −25 °C. The wind speed was expected to be between 0 and {{convert|11|m/s|km/h|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://vladivostoktimes.com/show/?id=32395&r=26&p= |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717230107/http://vladivostoktimes.com/show/?id=32395&r=26&p= |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2011-07-17 |title=Snow Cyclone is Coming to Primorye. The fall of temperature, snowstorm and glaze ice are forecasted in Vladivostok - Ecology - Vladivostok Times. Far East media news. Russian news. Vladivostok |publisher=Vladivostoktimes.com |accessdate=2010-02-26 }}</ref> Both ice and [[avalanche]] warnings were issued for a week (to December 2) as heavy snow was predicted for both [[Primorsky Krai]] and [[Amur Krai]], but significantly less than expected actually occurred over the week and the storm finally cleared up on 30 November, rather than on December 2.
A powerful storm (probably the earlier one from Primorsky Krai) stalled in the [[Gulf of Alaska]] on November 25. On the 26th, its wind field produced high tides on the western seaboard. The storm weakened significantly on the 27th and moved towards [[Southern California|Southern]] [[California]], bringing heavy rainfall starting early in the morning and causing strong winds. The storm left Southern California and moved on to batter the east coast during the afternoon of Sunday, November 29, 2009. A heavy and snowy [[cyclone]] hit the Aleutian islands on November 30.
By November 27 heavy rain was moving over the [[Irish Sea]] is set to give some heavy rain then turning to snow over parts of the [[Peak District]], with altitudes above 1000 feet (300 m), dropping over 2 inches (5.1 cm) of snow in some places. This is the usual snowfall for parts of [[Scotland]], including the [[West Highlands]] and the [[East Highlands]].
[[File:Workington North Station (RLM Byers).JPG|thumb|right|175px|Network Rail's new Workington [[Workington North|Workington North Temporary Station]] opened 30 November 2009.]]
In the U.K., [[Cumbria]]'s Workington North Temporary Station was officially opened on 30 November 2009.
On the 30th more than 100 people died as heavy rain flood [[Jeddah]], [[Saudi Arabia]]. The poorly designed and built local infrastructure and mismanagement of city works construction have been blamed, as well as the effects of [[Global Warming]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Victor Kaonga, Malawi |url=http://globalvoices.org/2009/11/30/saudi-arabia-citizens-fury-at-flood-deaths/ |title=Saudi Arabia: Citizens’ Fury At Flood Deaths · Global Voices |publisher=Globalvoices.org |accessdate=2011-03-19}}</ref>
==December==
=== December 1–2=== On December 1 and 2 heavy rain fell in the British Isles, and into the night, the [[rain band]] hit the [[cold wave|cold air]] and turned to snow giving about 1 foot (30 cm) on some hilltops and mountains across [[Scotland]].
On 2 December, thousands of acres of [[Ireland|Irish]] farmland remained underwater, floodwaters were still rising in some [[County Galway]] villages and roads in [[County Clare]] and Galway were still impassable.<ref name="Flooding eases in the west & midlands">{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/1202/weather.html|title=Flooding eases in the west & midlands|date=2009-12-02|accessdate=2009-12-04|publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]]}}</ref> Floods were still in situ across the UK and both bus and train services were disrupted in [[Essex]], [[Cumbria]] and [[Pembrokeshire]]. The [[River Severn]] and [[River Derwent, Cumbria|River Derwent]] were put on [[flood watch]] by the [[Environment Agency]].
===December 3 – January 1=== [[Toronto|Toronto, Ontario]], Canada was hit by both a cold front and two extreme cold weather warnings between December 3 and January 1.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2010-01/04/content_12749291.htm |title=Toronto calls off extreme cold weather alert_English_Xinhua |publisher=News.xinhuanet.com |date=2010-01-04 |accessdate=2010-02-26}}</ref> A strong arctic cold front moved through Alberta from the northwest, bringing from {{convert|4|in|mm}} to 1 foot (10 cm to 30 cm) of snowfall. Winds gusted to 50 mph (80 km/h), causing whiteout and blizzard conditions across most of Alberta. The southern half of the province got the worst of the storm. The winds blew the snow into massive drifts and snow banks up to 10 feet (3 m) in height. Numerous communities in [[Calgary]] were completely snowed in for three days, from December 5 to 7. Numerous cars and trucks were abandoned, with many of them buried up to their roofs in snow.
===December 4–7=== Between December 4–7 a heavy snow storm hit [[Calgary]] and disrupted travel in general Canada.<ref>http://coldunited.com/2009/.../snowstorms-calgary-edmonton-alberta-Canada/{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
===December 6–14=== The '''December 2009 North American snowstorms''' were a meteorological event in North America that started on December 11. The [[snowstorms]] brought record amounts of snow to the [[Midwest]] and contributed to deaths of 16 people.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/americas/8405500.stm |title=Snow storm moves on but leaves much of US shivering |publisher=BBC News |date=10 December 2009 |accessdate=14 December 2009}}</ref> The storms affected a number of [[List of US states|US states]], including [[Arizona]], [[Wisconsin]] and New York, as well as Canada. Although the initial storm had virtually subsided by December 11, further snow was expected to fall.<ref name="Central Network News">{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/US/weather/12/10/winter.weather/index.html?eref=rss_topstories |title=Winter storm exits, but another is brewing |publisher=CNN |date=December 11, 2009 |accessdate=December 14, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-12/21/content_12681257.htm |title=U.S. East Coast in mess after record-setting storm_English_Xinhua |publisher=News.xinhuanet.com |date=2009-12-21 |accessdate=2010-02-26}}</ref>
A weak disturbance that started overnight on December 6 stalled over the western United States and intensified rapidly. Heavy downpours began early in the morning of December 7 and continued non-stop until the evening, triggering flash-flood watches. The storm dropped as much as 4.5 in (110 mm) of rain in [[Cuyamaca]], San Diego, causing blackouts in some locations. This storm was followed by a small semi-tropical winter storm which started overnight on December 10 and then stalled over [[Southern California]] and intensified, causing heavy downpours. In addition to {{convert|4|in|mm}} of rain, this storm gave [[pea]]-sized-[[hail]] and gusty winds before weakening and moving away from Southern California on December 13.
Heavy snow hit [[Wisconsin]], [[New York (state)|New York]], Washington, D.C. and parts of [[Maryland]] on the 10th and 14th. Heavy rain hit parts of [[Arizona]] on the 11th.
In Vancouver, BC a strong winter storm deposited anywhere from 10–30 cm of heavy snow from the night of the 12th through to the morning of the 15th after a frigid arctic air that had been over the region for days with as low as -15 °C temperatures met with moist Pacific air.
===December 8–16=== Light snow began to fall in the [[Grampian Mountains]] on December 8. On the 8th more heavy snow showers followed on the 18th. Heavy overnight snow caused widespread disruption across England in the South East, East Anglia, the East Midlands and Yorkshire and the Humber. East Winds brought further snowfalls in the northern half of the UK.
Overnight, five [[Eurostar]] trains were stuck in the [[Channel Tunnel]], trapping 2,000 people for 16 hours after electrical failures due to cold temperatures. Many schools in England were closed on the 9th. During the [[December 2009 European snowfall]], four Eurostar trains broke down inside the Channel Tunnel, after leaving France, and one in Kent on 18 December. Although the trains had been [[Winterization|winterised]], the systems had not coped with the conditions.<ref name="tel1">{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/transport/6856009/Eurostar-launches-independent-review.html|title=Eurostar launches independent review|first=Caroline|last=Gammell|date=2009-12-21|work=The Telegraph | location=London | accessdate=2010-04-06}}</ref> Over 2,000 passengers were stuck inside failed trains inside the tunnel, and over 75,000 had their services disrupted.<ref name="fig2">{{cite news|url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/flash-actu/2009/12/21/01011-20091221FILWWW00634-eurostar-ameliorer-l-info-dans-le-tunnel.php|title=Eurostar: "améliorer l'info dans le tunnel"|date=2009-12-21|work=Le Figaro|language=French}}</ref> All Eurostar services were cancelled from Saturday 19 December to Monday 21 December 2009.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2009/dec/21/eurostar-inquiry-passengers-stranded-trains|title=Eurostar services suspended for third day as bad weather hits flights|last=Gabbatt|first=Adam|author2=agencies|date= 21 December 2009|work=The Guardian|accessdate=21 December 2009 | location=London}}</ref> An independent review, published on 12 February 2010, was critical of the contingency plans in place for assisting passengers stranded by the delays, calling them "insufficient".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/8511857.stm|title=Eurostar handling of snow delays criticised |date= 12 February 2010|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=13 February 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.eurostarindependentreview.org/pdf/Eurostar%20Independent%20Review.pdf|title=Eurostar Independent Review |date= 12 February 2010|accessdate=13 February 2010}}</ref>
The cold weather began in earnest on December 10, with temperatures in [[Braemar]], [[Aberdeenshire]] reaching a low of −4.9 °C on the 10th, −7 °C on the 11th, and −8.9 °C on the 12th. This was the beginning of the "[[Big Freeze]]". Between December 11 and 16, cold air from the north and east brought subzero temperatures to many northern parts of the UK and the southern county of [[Oxfordshire]], along with dense fog.
===December 14–21=== [[File:Paris France December 17.jpg|thumb|right|upright=0.75|Paris, France, on 17 December]] [[File:Peterborough snow 09.jpg|thumb|left|upright=0.75|[[Peterborough]], England, on 18 December]]
A major blizzard killed 11 people in [[Romania]] between December 14 and 21.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-12/21/content_12684109.htm |title=11 killed by cold weather in Romania _English_Xinhua |publisher=News.xinhuanet.com |date=2009-12-21 |accessdate=2010-02-26}}</ref>
Wintery showers of rain, sleet, and heavy snow affected East and South-East parts of the United Kingdom. On 18 December, heavy [[snowfall]] caused widespread disruption and travel chaos across large parts of [[Lancashire]], [[South East England]], [[East Anglia]], the [[East Midlands]] and [[Yorkshire and the Humber]], forcing schools to close early for the upcoming Christmas holiday and cutting power supplies in some areas.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8420057.stm|title= Heavy snow causes travel chaos in parts of England|publisher= BBC News|date= 18 December 2009|accessdate= 18 December 2009}}</ref> The heaviest snowfall in 20 years also caused temperatures to fall as low as {{convert|-16|C}} in the Scottish Highlands.
More heavy snow showers followed on December 18. Heavy overnight snow caused widespread disruption across England in the South East, East Anglia, the East Midlands, Yorkshire, and the Humber. Five [[Eurostar]] trains were stuck in the [[Channel Tunnel]] after electrical failures due to cold temperatures, trapping 2,000 people for up to 16 hours. Many schools in England were closed on December 18.
Heavy snowfall and sub-zero temperatures killed at least 290 people across Europe. Temperatures fell to as low as {{convert|-33|C}} in Germany, suspending and cancelling flights and stranding thousands of Christmas passengers. As many as 40% of flights from Paris's two airports, [[Orly Airport|Orly]] and [[Charles de Gaulle Airport|Charles de Gaulle]], were cancelled. [[Berlin Tegel Airport]], Amsterdam's Schiphol Airport, and [[Frankfurt International Airport]] were forced to close due to ice on the runway.
Heavy snow fell in both the Russian territories of [[Krasnodar Krai]]<ref>http://images.google.co.uk/imgres?imgurl=http://www.russiablog.org/sakhalin-snowstormed-main.jpg&imgrefurl=http://www.russiablog.org/photos/&usg=__tjgtp_RrrVDm5GzuID1-nHIQEyM=&h=267&w=400&sz=52&hl=en&start=7&itbs=1&tbnid=3S0BDANKqmJ0CM:&tbnh=83&tbnw=124&prev=/images%3Fq%3Dsnow%2Bstorms%2Bsakhalin%2Bisland%2Baugust%2B2009%26hl%3Den%26safe%3Dactive%26tbs%3Disch:1<!-- don't know if it has a title, so feel free to add one. This will still look horrible in print... --></ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.russiablog.org/photos/ |title=Photos Archive |publisher=Russia Blog |accessdate=2010-02-26}}</ref> and in the [[Russian Far East]] on December the 18th. The Far Eastern storm had heavy [[snow flurries]] occurred across the [[Sea of Okhotsk]], [[Cape Lopatka]], [[Avacha Bay]], [[Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky]], [[Volcanoes of Kamchatka]], which a [[UNESCO World Heritage Site]] in the [[Kamchatka Peninsula]]'s [[Central Range Mountains]] on December the 18th.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://images.google.co.uk/imgres?imgurl=http://www.eosnap.com/public/media/2009/03/russia/20090317-russia-full.jpg&imgrefurl=http://www.eosnap.com/%3Ftag%3Dsea-of-okhotsk&usg=__0WKHM7yQuOkcJX620EhU5zAjr8o=&h=1312&w=1057&sz=550&hl=en&start=6&itbs=1&tbnid=mrcUx-k6G7B9-M:&tbnh=150&tbnw=121&prev=/images%3Fq%3Dsnow%2Bstorms%2Bsakhalin%2Bisland%2Baugust%2B2009%26hl%3Den%26safe%3Dactive%26tbs%3Disch:1 |title=Google Image Result for http://www.eosnap.com/public/media/2009/03/russia/20090317-russia-full.jpg |publisher=Images.google.co.uk |accessdate=2010-02-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eosnap.com/?tag=sea-of-okhotsk |title=Earth Snapshot • Sea of Okhotsk |publisher=Eosnap.com |accessdate=2010-02-26}}</ref>
[[File:Wroclaw snow 09.jpg|thumb|right|175px|[[Wrocław]], Poland, on 20 December.]] On December 20, 3 people froze to death in Steiermark, Austria,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-12/21/content_12679197.htm |title=3 dead in Austrian cold wave this winter_English_Xinhua |publisher=[[Xinhua News Agency]]|date=2009-12-21 |accessdate=2010-02-26}}</ref> while blizzards hit S.W. Norway.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-12/21/content_12679180.htm |title=Heavy snowfall causes traffic chaos in SW Norway_English_Xinhua |publisher=[[Xinhua News Agency]]|date=2009-12-21 |accessdate=2010-02-26}}</ref> December 21 and 22 saw 20 cm of snow fall in Moscow and nearby towns <ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-12/21/content_12683648.htm |title=Heavy snowfall brings Moscow transport chaos_English_Xinhua |publisher=News.xinhuanet.com |date=2009-12-21 |accessdate=2010-02-26}}</ref> Temperatures of as low as −20 °C killed 47 people in Poland on December 20.<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.google.com/hostednews/canadianpress/article/ALeqM5gV8Rxf2WHME7XwVV0USEblrKvHxQ|title= 15 people die as temperatures fall far below freezing|publisher= The Canadian Press|date= 20 December 2009|accessdate= 20 December 2009}}</ref> In northern Italy, some locations recorded the lowest temperature since 1985, with one low reaching −17 °C (1.4 °F).<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.meteogiornale.it/notizia/16901-1-il-gelo-del-20-dicembre-2009-e-gia-storia|date=2009-12-21|accessdate= 2015-10-30|language=it|title=Il gelo del 20 dicembre 2009 è già storia|first1=Stefano|last1=Di Battista|publisher=Meteo Giornale S.r.l}}</ref> Finland, the UK, Belgium, and the Netherlands also recorded record low temperatures.
In the United Kingdom, many major [[motorways]], including the [[M25 motorway|M25]], [[M4 motorway|M4]], [[M40 motorway|M40]] and [[M1 motorway|M1]], were brought to a standstill due to [[snow drift]]s, cold, and ice, leaving many towns gridlocked. The UK's [[Highways Agency]] tried to grit the [[M11 motorway|M11]] and M1, only to have a gritter van skid off the M11 and into a deep snow drift. Some people were able to travel from [[London Victoria Station]] to [[Ashford International railway station]] courtesy of a [[steam locomotive|steam train]] hauled by ''[[LNER Peppercorn Class A1 60163 Tornado|Tornado]]''.<ref name=BBC8428097 >{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/8428097.stm |title=Steam train's snow rescue 'glory' |publisher=BBC News Online |accessdate=23 December 2009 | date=2009-12-23}}</ref> Widespread transport disruption to roads, railways, buses, and airports affected much of England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland.<ref name=coldweather >{{cite news|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8424338.stm|title= Cold weather causes travel disruption across the UK|publisher= BBC News|date= 21 December 2009|accessdate= 21 December 2009}}</ref>
In [[Zagreb]], [[Croatia]], around 50 passengers were injured when a train travelling from [[Sisak]] to Zagreb failed to stop due to [[black ice]] on the rails and hit a buffer at the city's main [[Zagreb Main Station|railway station]]. One person suffered life-threatening injuries, while some 40 others required medical attention. A [[homeless]] man froze to death in southern [[Kosovo]] during a localized snowstorm. In [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]], 3 people were found dead from [[hypothermia]] in [[Sarajevo]] and [[Teslić]].<ref>[http://www.b92.net/eng/news/region-article.php?yyyy=2009&mm=12&dd=21&nav_id=63926 "Three people freeze to death in Bosnia"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100116082104/http://www.b92.net/eng/news/region-article.php?yyyy=2009&mm=12&dd=21&nav_id=63926 |date=2010-01-16 }} ''b92.net'' 21 December 2009 Link retrieved 21 December 2009</ref>
===December 16–19=== {{Main|North American blizzard of 2009}} [[File:Blizzard aftermath car + 23.5 inches of snow.jpg|thumb|right|175px|Cars buried by nearly {{convert|24|in|cm}} of snow in [[Woodley Park, Washington, D.C.]], on December 19.]]
A powerful [[nor'easter]] brought blizzard conditions to the [[Northeastern United States|northeastern]] and [[Mid-Atlantic States|mid-atlantic]] United States, as well as [[Nova Scotia]] in Canada on the 16th of December. Washington, D.C. received nearly two feet (over 60 cm) of snow, setting a city record for December snowfall. New York City and southern [[New England]] were forecast to receive over a foot of snow.<ref>Morello, Carol and Halsey, Ashley. [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/12/19/AR2009121900741.html?hpid=todays-paper "Massive storm cripples region"], WashingtonPost.com, accessed 19 Dec 2009.</ref> The snow covered most of [[New England]], disrupting travel in [[New York (state)|New York]] and [[Pennsylvania]] <ref name="msnbc.msn.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/34477381/ns/weather/ |title=East Coast returns to work — slowly - Weather- msnbc.com |publisher=MSNBC |date=2009-12-21 |accessdate=2010-02-26}}</ref> as local record low temperatures are recorded as [[List of snow events in Florida|snow falls]] in [[Florida]] on the 17th.<ref name="msnbc.msn.com"/> Seven people were killed as a result of the storm.
19 December 2009 also saw a meeting of both [[Meteorology|meteorological]] <!-- ? -->, [[provincial capitals|provincial]] and [[government]]al officials from across [[Eastern Siberia]] and the neighbouring provinces of [[Northeast China]] on how to cope with any future severe storms in southern [[Sakhalin Island]] and [[Heilongjiang]] Province. 8 people had died on the island by this date<ref>{{cite web|author=Sat, 19 Dec 2009 |url=http://archive.wn.com/2009/12/19/1400/sakhalintv/ |title=Sakhalin TV |publisher=Archive.wn.com |accessdate=2011-03-19}}</ref><ref>[http://www.wildsalmoncenter.org/pdf/SSI accomplishments 2009.PDF]</ref>
===December 20–22=== On December 20, nearly a foot and a half of snow fell in parts of [[Buncombe County]] and around other parts of [[North Carolina]], with the highest amounts seen north and east of [[Transylvania County]].<ref name="citizen-times.com"/> This was the most snow seen in the region since 1996. Two feet of snow was recorded on [[Mt. Mitchell]]. [[National Guard of the United States|National Guard]] units were mobilized to help stranded drivers and clear roads.<ref name="citizen-times.com">http://www.citizen-times.com/article/20091220/NEWS01/312200052{{dead link|date=February 2010}}</ref> [[Red Cross]] and National Guard shelters were opened in Buncombe, Madison and McDowell counties to accommodate travellers stranded by miles-long backups on the congested and debris-strewn I-40 and I-26.<ref name="citizen-times.com"/> Hundreds of trees and limbs fell under the weight of the snow, blocking roads and leaving tens of thousands without power or phones.<ref name="citizen-times.com"/> On December 22, blizzard conditions also struck Washington, D.C.<ref name="rt.com">{{cite web|url=http://rt.com/Top_News/2009-12-22/snow-moscow-snowfall-traffic.html |title=Moscow presses on while snow storms cripple Europe & US - RT Top Stories |publisher=Rt.com |accessdate=2010-02-26}}</ref> Snow fall would be widely spread across the north eastern USA and most of the [[East Coast of the United States|Eastern Seaboard]].<ref name="gulfnews.com">{{cite web|url=http://gulfnews.com/news/world/usa/snow-storms-whack-us-and-europe-1.555883 |title=Snow, storms whack US and Europe |publisher=gulfnews |date=2009-12-20 |accessdate=2011-03-19}}</ref>
On December 20 snow near the city of [[Hanover]] caused miles-long traffic jams on the [[Autobahn]]. There had been road 50 accidents reported on the stretch of Autobahn, which only has 5-6 accident a day in normal weather.<ref name="english.cctv.com">{{cite web|url=http://english.cctv.com/program/worldwidewatch/20091220/101503.shtml |title=Storm causes chaos in Poland and Germany CCTV-International |publisher=English.cctv.com |date=2009-12-20 |accessdate=2011-03-19}}</ref> The trains running between [[Warsaw]] and [[Poznań]] were delayed by at least an hour due to snow drifts on the tracks and fallen [[power lines]]. The [[Polish Meteorological Institute]] predicted the weather would not change for the next few days and temperatures would stay at -10C for the next couple of days.<ref name="english.cctv.com"/> Poland, northern Germany, [[Scandinavia]], [[Lithuania]] and Hungary would all see at least some heavy snow in places that day. Light snow was reported in most parts on [[continental Europe]] and the UK by the 22nd. Twenty-three [[association football|football]] matches and two [[horse races]] were called off in the UK.<ref name="gulfnews.com"/>
===December 21–January 3=== In [[Mongolia]], heavy December [[snowstorms]] killed 2,000 cattle and 2 people. The worst of the snowstorms occurred between December 21 and January 3.
===December 21–22=== On December 21 blizzards disrupted [[New England]], south western [[Ukraine]], [[Düsseldorf]], [[Frankfurt]], [[Bosnia]], [[Serbia]], Paris, the Netherlands and London.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/europe/news/article_1520687.php/Winter-storm-hits-Europe-North-America-with-heavy-snow |title=Winter storm hits Europe, North America with heavy snow |publisher=Monsters and Critics |date=2009-12-21 |accessdate=2011-03-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100901004736/http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/europe/news/article_1520687.php/Winter-storm-hits-Europe-North-America-with-heavy-snow |archivedate=2010-09-01 |df= }}</ref>
On December 22, a blanket of heavy snow fell upon large parts of Japan and [[South Korea]], causing the deaths of 10 Japanese and 3 South Korean people. Snow was piled up to 184 cm high in parts of [[Niigata Prefecture|Niigata]]. Up to 650,000 homes and businesses lost electricity, and local trains were also halted by the power outage.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/world/story/2005/12/22/japansnow051222.html |title=CBC News - World - Japan, South Korea, hit by snowstorm |publisher=Cbc.ca |date=2005-12-22 |accessdate=2010-02-26}}</ref> In [[Fukui Prefecture|Fukui]], two [[nuclear power]] plants automatically shut down due to technical problems caused by the unusually heavy snowfalls. South Korea deployed several thousand troops to clear highways and remove snow from the roofs of weak buildings after up to a metre of snow had fallen over the past two weeks. Although the storm certainly affected [[North Korea]] as well, no reports are available.
Also on the 22nd, snowstorms hit [[Leicestershire]] and [[Warsaw]].<ref name="rt.com"/> At the same time, a Winter storm hit Moscow,<ref name="rt.com"/> [[Saint Petersburg]], and parts of [[Tannu Tuva]], while a [[Siberian cyclone]] started up over [[Sakha Republic|Yakutia]] and headed for [[Khabarovsk Krai]].
===December 22–28=== {{Main|2009 North American Christmas winter storm}}
[[File:2009 Christmas Storm 12-24.jpg|thumb|right|175px|The 2009 American Christmas Winter Storm on December 24 over the Southeast United States.]]
Starting on December 22, a large winter storm began moving across the [[Great Plains]] and [[Midwest]].<ref name="BBC December 24 storm">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/8429618.stm|title=Deadly winter storm arrives in US Midwest |date=December 24, 2009|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=24 December 2009}}</ref> It claimed 21 lives, canceled hundreds of flights and knocked out power across most of [[West Virginia]].<ref name="BBC December 24 storm" /><ref name="Reuters December 24 storm">{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE5BM3JV20091224|title=Blizzard warnings for central U.S. before Christmas|last=Davis|first= Meredith |date=December 24, 2009|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=24 December 2009}}</ref> The storm stalled and spun around itself for a few days before continuing northeast. Many parts of the Great Plains experienced heavy snowfall, while places further north such as [[Chicago]] and [[Ottawa]] received freezing rain.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.wsbt.com/news/local/80050157.html |title=Ice storm, freezing rain begin to impact Christmas Eve travel |last=Stopczynski |first=Kelli |date=December 23, 2009 |publisher=WSBT-News |accessdate=24 December 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091226153954/http://www.wsbt.com/news/local/80050157.html |archivedate=December 26, 2009 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/ottawa/story/2009/12/27/ott-freezing-rain-power-outages.html |title=Power outages hit E. Ontario, Quebec |publisher=CBC |date=December 27, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091231133700/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/ottawa/story/2009/12/27/ott-freezing-rain-power-outages.html |archivedate=December 31, 2009 |df= }}</ref> As the snow and rain subsided on the 27th, it left record rainfalls in [[Texas]] to the Upper Midwest. The storm dumped 23.9 in (60.7 cm) of snow in [[Grand Forks, North Dakota]], and 18 in (45.7 cm) near Norfolk, [[Nebraska]].<ref name="hurriyetdailynews.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/wires.php?id=3358605_us-holiday-storm-omaha-nebraska-snow-cold-rain-that-battered-much-of-us-leave-behind-flooding-concerns-in-some-areas |title=Snow, cold rain that battered much of US leave behind flooding concerns in some areas |publisher=Hurriyetdailynews.com |date=2009-12-27 |accessdate=2010-02-26}}</ref> In the East, higher temperatures and rains have started melting and washing away last week's record-setting snowfalls, threatening the region with flooding.<ref name="hurriyetdailynews.com"/> The [[National Weather Service]] also of flooding in parts of the South and Midwest, and [[Winter Weather Advisory|winter weather advisories]] were in effect in sections of [[Nebraska]], [[Illinois]], [[Indiana]] and [[Michigan]] through the Sunday.<ref name="hurriyetdailynews.com"/> A man drowned after slipping into the [[Kennebec River]], near [[Moosehead Lake]] in [[Maine]].
Over {{convert|30|in|cm}} of snow fell in [[South Dakota]]. Several inches of snow also fell in the [[Las Vegas Valley]], [[Nevada]]. In southern [[Ontario]], [[snowsquall]]s fed into a [[cold front]] behind the main low pressure center of the storm to produce a rapid drop in temperatures on December 28.
===December 23–January 1=== December 23 to 26 saw heavy snow hit both [[Primorsky Krai|Primorsky (Primorye) Krai]], [[Khabarovsk Krai]], [[Sakhalin Oblast]] and [[Kamchatka Krai]].<ref name="vladivostoktimes.com">{{cite web|url=http://vladivostoktimes.com/show/?id=46237 |title=At Weekend Primorye to be Covered with Snow. A migratory cyclone bringing a warm spell and snowstorm is reaching Primorye on Friday - Ecology - Vladivostok Times. Far East media news. Russian news. Vladivostok |publisher=Vladivostoktimes.com |accessdate=2010-02-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717230040/http://vladivostoktimes.com/show/?id=46237 |archivedate=2011-07-17 |df= }}</ref><ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite web|url=http://vladivostoktimes.com/content/photo.php?id=46237&f=64121&mode=pub |title=Фото 25 декабря 2009, 12:00. At Weekend Primorye to be Covered with Snow - PrimaMedia. Последние новости Владивостока, Приморский край, Приморье, Дальний Восток |publisher=Vladivostoktimes.com |accessdate=2010-02-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717230155/http://vladivostoktimes.com/content/photo.php?id=46237&f=64121&mode=pub |archivedate=2011-07-17 |df= }}</ref> The weekend saw a migratory cyclone bringing a warm spell and snowstorms reaching Primorsky on the Friday.<ref name="vladivostoktimes.com"/><ref name="ReferenceA"/> Heavy snow badly disrupted life in [[Vladivostok]] in December as sleet and gale-force wind occurred on Primorsky Krai's south coast.<ref name="vladivostoktimes.com"/><ref name="ReferenceA"/> Over two days, temperatures rose from -4 °C up to -2 °C. On the night of December 26 the strengthening [[cyclone]] began drifting to the southern coast of Primorsky and over Sakhalin Krai.<ref name="vladivostoktimes.com"/><ref name="ReferenceA"/> Snow also fell in [[Amur Oblast]]. President [[Vladimir Putin]] visited Vladivostok on the 25th.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://vladivostoktimes.com/show/?id=46353 |title=Vladimir Putin Arrives in Vladivostok. The RF Prime Minister took part in the ceremony of ESPO oil pipeline launching - Politics - Vladivostok Times. Far East media news. Russian news. Vladivostok |publisher=Vladivostoktimes.com |accessdate=2010-02-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717230055/http://vladivostoktimes.com/show/?id=46353 |archivedate=2011-07-17 |df= }}</ref>
Heavy snowfall also began in [[Saint Petersburg]], Russia. By December 26, the city was under 35 cm of snow, creating the most December snowfall seen in the city since 1881.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://en.rian.ru/russia/20091226/157384463.html|title= Snowstorm in St. Petersburg causes delay of 14 flights|publisher= RIA Novosti|date= 26 December 2009|accessdate= 11 January 2009}}</ref> A snowstorm also occurred in parts of the [[Barents sea]].
On December 30, an emergency warning about the passage of another powerful cyclone was issued to all the territories and population centres along Russia's Pacific Coast.<ref name="itar-tass.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.itar-tass.com/eng/level2.html?NewsID=14689123&PageNum=0 |title=Itar-Tass |publisher=Itar-Tass |accessdate=2010-02-26}}</ref> The gales, heavy snowfall, blizzards and a sharp fall in air temperatures hit the [[Sea of Okhotsk]] and the surrounding territories of Primorsky Krai, Sakhalin Oblast, Khabarovsk Krai and [[Magadan Oblast]].<ref name="itar-tass.com"/> The Far Eastern territorial centre of the federal Ministry for Emergency Situations and Civil Defence (E.M.E.R.C.O.M.) warned that the cyclone would produce [[snow drift|snow banks]], icy conditions on roads, as well as snow bringing down phone and [[power transmission lines]] in Primorsky territory.<ref name="itar-tass.com"/> The temperatures reckoned to have fallen near the expected −7 °C. The temperature was that which usually occurs in a [[Siberian]] cyclone, when it reaches the [[Russian Far East]].<ref name="itar-tass.com"/> Forecasters said there was a strong possibility of heavy snowfall and blizzards along the eastern districts of the Khabarovsk Krai, in parts of the [[Sakhalin Island]] and on the southern [[Kuril Islands]] December 31 and January 1.<ref name="itar-tass.com"/>
The last week of 2009 saw an [[Arctic storm]] bearing down on [[Sakhalin Island]], and local officials told people not to drive their cars outside any city limits and banned the rather dangerous practice of [[ice fishing]], due to the purported death of a [[Nivkh people|Nivkh]] [[fisherman]], until the storm had passed.<ref name="nytimes.com">{{cite news|last=Barry |first=Ellen |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/04/world/europe/04sakhalin.html |title=Harsh Storm Batters Island Off the Coast of Russia |location=Russia;Sakhalin Island (Russia) |publisher=NYTimes.com |date=2010-01-03 |accessdate=2010-02-26}}</ref> Nonetheless, dozens of cars were buried in snow and in one village, rescuers dug out 56 cars, freeing 74 passengers and giving aid to those who were haplessly trapped.<ref name="nytimes.com"/> People in cars that remained stuck were being provided with both water, bread and fuel via snowmobile.<ref name="nytimes.com"/> The towns of [[Korsakov (town)|Korsakov]] and [[Poronaysk]] were worst hit, and parts of the local [[taiga]] forests of fir and birch had been entirely up-rooted and buried by the blizzard conditions.<ref>http://www.deznoyas.com/2010/01/03/world/europe/14russia.html{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
===December 25–30 === About 60% of the Italian city of [[Venice]] was flooded by a heavy [[rainstorm]] on December the 25th.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.euronews.net/2009/12/25/flood-waters-rising-in-venice/ |title=Flood waters rising in Venice - Weather : news, world |publisher=euronews |accessdate=2010-02-26}}</ref>
[[File:Glen Coe, Scotland 27 Dec.jpg|thumb|right|175px|[[Glen Coe]], Scotland, on 27 December.]] [[File:Aircraft in the snow at Leeds Bradford Airport.jpg|thumb|175px|right|[[Leeds Bradford Airport]] following heavy snowfall on 27 December 2009.]]
Parts of England again suffered repeated power cuts,<ref name="electric1">{{cite web|url=http://www.electric.co.uk/news/tag/power-cuts |title=Power Cuts | Electric.co.uk News |publisher=Electric.co.uk |accessdate={{date|2010-01-09}} |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090819205616/http://www.electric.co.uk/news/tag/power-cuts |archivedate=2009-08-19 |df= }}</ref> and Scotland experienced fresh snowfall overnight on 26–27 December with the worst affected area being [[Perthshire]], where between {{convert|12|and(-)|18|in}} fell.<ref name="Webster">{{cite news |url=http://www.pressandjournal.co.uk/Article.aspx/1540191?UserKey= |title=Roads havoc as temperature plummets |publisher=Press and Journal |first=Catriona |last=Webster |date=28 December 2009 |accessdate=28 December 2009}}</ref><ref name="Webster"/>
Temperatures dropped to {{convert|-18|C}} in parts of the Highlands overnight on 28–29 December, with [[Braemar]] recording Britain's lowest temperature of the winter. Fresh travel warnings were issued on 29 December as the wintry conditions continued to cause problems on Scotland's roads.
The runway of [[Inverness Airport]] was briefly closed because of snow and ice, and [[First ScotRail]] reduced services to and from [[Glasgow Central railway station|Glasgow Central]] because of the severe conditions.
The snow and icy conditions were good for the Scottish [[ski]] industry, which said the weather helped it to experience its best start to the season for several years.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/8432460.stm |title=Travel warnings issued over wintry conditions |publisher=BBC News |date=29 December 2009 |accessdate=30 December 2009}}</ref>
Warnings of heavy snow were issued for Wales, the Midlands, north-west England, eastern and southern England, and Yorkshire and Humber.<ref name=BBC30Dec09b >{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8432437.stm |title=Snow hits Wales and the Midlands with more to come |publisher=BBC News |date=29 December 2009 |accessdate=31 December 2009}}</ref> More snow began falling across parts of Wales and central and northern England on the evening of 29 December, with Wales recording the heaviest of the snow showers where some rural areas were cut off by of up to {{convert|30|cm}}. Snow was also reported in parts of the [[West Midlands (region)|West Midlands region]] and [[Yorkshire]].
In Italy, December 30 saw hundreds of homes in [[Tuscany]] evacuated because of flooding and Spain's rescue services were on yellow danger alert after flash floods destroyed roads and landslides swept railways away.<ref name="euronews.net">{{cite web|url=http://www.euronews.net/2009/12/30/continent-shivers-in-rain-and-snow-storms/ |title=Continent shivers in rain and snow storms - Weather : news, world |publisher=euronews |accessdate=2010-02-26}}</ref> Transport Links between [[Almeria]], [[Granada]], [[Málaga]] and [[Sevilla]] were severed. Drought-blighted [[Andalusia]] has had its fifth day of rain, and Portugal was on orange flood alert.<ref name="euronews.net"/> Authorities said the rain had destroyed millions of Euros worth of agricultural produce.<ref name="euronews.net"/> The [[harbour]]s were closed and the [[Madeira]] archipelago islands were also under threat of both flooding and gale-force winds, as 110 km/h whipped up six-metre -high waves.<ref name="euronews.net"/>
===December 28–January 3=== At least two of the Russian Far East storms stacked up over the [[Gulf of Alaska]] during December 28. Various [[weather forecast]]s suggested that one would spread valley rain and mountain snow across [[Northern California]] and drop up to half an inch of rain across the northern [[Sacramento Valley]] <ref name="redding.com">{{cite web |author=primalux writes: |url=http://www.redding.com/news/2009/dec/28/it-will-be-a-damp-end-for-2009-in-north-state/ |title=It will be a damp end for 2009 in north state |publisher=Redding Record Searchlight |accessdate=2010-02-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100315132656/http://www.redding.com/news/2009/dec/28/it-will-be-a-damp-end-for-2009-in-north-state/ |archivedate=2010-03-15 |df= }}</ref> over the next few days. The [[National Weather Service]] issued a [[Winter Weather Advisory]] warning for the [[Mount Shasta]] area,<ref name="redding.com"/> where forecasters expected 1 to {{convert|3|in|mm}} of snow in town and up to {{convert|10|in|mm}} above {{convert|5000|ft|m}}. The second cold front, and its related storm, would bring more rain and high country snow to the north state by [[New Year's Eve]] or [[New Year's Day]].<ref name="redding.com"/>
The blizzards began on [[New Year's Eve]], and lasted until January 3. The worst of the blizzards occurred on December 31, when an [[avalanche]] [[derailment|derailed]] a [[diesel locomotive]] fitted with a railway [[snowplough]] off its railway tracks.<ref name="nytimes.com"/> The storm continued through 1 January, when three workers sent to repair the damage were swept away by the howling [[blizzard]] that was ripping through [[Sakhalin Island]] according to the [[RIA Novosti]] news service.<ref name="nytimes.com"/> One worker was found alive and rescue teams retrieved the body of a second Sunday morning.<ref name="nytimes.com"/> The situation worsened to the point that 140 [[soldiers]] were ordered to help dig the train out from beneath {{convert|350,000|cuft|m3}} of snow.<ref name="nytimes.com"/> A local man, Andrei Sukhonosov, trying to return home to the city of [[Tomari, Russia|Tomari]] was on the buried train.<ref name="nytimes.com"/> <ref name="nytimes.com"/><ref>http://www.lablonc.com/2010/01/05/world/asia/02snow.html{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>http://www.origonaljoans.com/2010/01/05/world/europe/05ice{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>http://www.deshatner.com/2010/01/05/world/europe/02ice.html{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
Authorities and rescue services in [[Sakhalin Oblast]] were put on alert, and warned of a high risk of [[avalanche]]s on the island's numerous hills and mountains.<ref name="itar-tass.com"/> Another avalanche warning was issued on the 2nd, for [[Sakhalin Island]], due to hazardous levels of [[snowfall]] during yet another [[Siberian snow cyclone]] and [[blizzard]], emergency officials said.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/International/2010/01/02/Russian-island-enduring-snow-cyclone/UPI-19541262458995/ |title=Russian island enduring snow cyclone |publisher=UPI.com |date=2010-01-02 |accessdate=2010-02-26}}</ref> The authorities in Primorsky and [[Khabarovsk Krai]] were also put on alert, just in case things got ant worse.<ref name="itar-tass.com"/> The last two [[Russian Far East]]ern storms dissipated in the [[Gulf of Alaska]] on January 5 and 6 respectively.
===December 29–31=== Following the deadly [[2009 North American Christmas winter storm]], a medium-sized [[nor'easter]] formed in [[Texas]] and brought moderate snow to the western portion of the state on December 29. In anticipation of the event Texas Governor [[Rick Perry]] activated his resources ahead of the winter storm.<ref name="KLTV1">{{cite news|url=http://www.kltv.com/Global/story.asp?S=11741942|title=Gov. Perry activates resources ahead of winter storm|last=Hetrick|first=Michael|date=December 29, 2009|publisher=KLTV-NEWS|accessdate=29 December 2009}}</ref> It then moved through the Southeast and brought heavy rain and freezing rain to higher altitudes. Some snow was reported in [[Clayton, Georgia]] but did not accumulate. It then moved quickly up the [[East Coast of the United States]], bringing freezing rain and sleet to the [[Mid-Atlantic states|Mid-Atlantic]] and moderate to heavy snow to the Tri-State Area (New York, New Jersey, Connecticut). 5 inches (12.7 cm) at the most was reported in [[White Plains, New York|White Plains]] 4.5 inches (11.4 cm) in [[Hartford]]. It then brought about 2 inches (5 cm) to [[Boston]] and southeastern [[New England]]. Overnight January 1, it strengthened explosively over water and looped back around to create a [[blizzard]] in northern New England.
